headline: Vance parlays Trump endorsement into new Thiel money
sentences: Thiel has donated $3.5 million to Protect Ohio Values, the super PAC backing Vance, according to a person familiar with the contribution  part of a broader tranche of money that has come in to support the Senate candidate after last week's Trump endorsement, which shook up a crowded and competitive race for the GOP nomination.
The organization has been trying to combat the pro-Mandel Club for Growth, which has spent millions of dollars assailing Vance and is expected to continue to invest heavily ahead of the primary.
Through the end of March, Vance's campaign had just $1.6 million in the bank, a fraction of the amount reported by two of Vance's closest competitors, Josh Mandel and Mike Gibbons.
Thiel, a close Trump ally, earlier this year held a fundraiser for Wyoming Republican Harriet Hageman, who is running to unseat GOP Rep. Liz Cheney, an outspoken Trump critic.
With his new donation, the PayPal co-founder and early Facebook investor has given $13.5 million to the pro-Vance super PAC, after seeding it with $10 million last year.
Vance is cashing in on his endorsement from former President Donald Trump with a major new super PAC donation from billionaire tech investor Peter Thiel.
Vance's campaign has already taken steps to capitalize on the Trump endorsement, with his campaign taking to the TV airwaves with TV ads promoting it.
And Protect Ohio Values, after going off the air last week, has so far booked more than $1.3 million in ads in Ohio this week, according to AdImpact.
Thiel has been an active participant in the Vance and Masters campaigns, staying up to date on the developments in their respective primaries.
His support has helped Vance and Masters attract a wave of Silicon Valley-based donors who do not typically back Republican candidates.
Protect Ohio Values, meanwhile, reported having under $300,000 in the bank at the end of March after spending Thiel's initial donation.
Vance, a Republican running for an open U.S. Senate seat in Ohio, is fundraising off the endorsement by former President Donald Trump.
He has also dished out $10 million to a super PAC backing his former de facto chief of staff, Arizona Senate candidate Blake Masters.
Club for Growth has been reminding voters of comments Vance made during the 2016 presidential race attacking Trump.
He has separately accompanied them to meetings with Trump, and he has held fundraising events for them.
The 54-year-old, German-born Thiel has emerged as one of the Republican Party's most prominent donors.
The funding could go a long way toward bolstering Vance ahead of the May 3 primary.

Paul Vernon | AP
By Alex Isenstadt
 04/19/2022 03:37 PM EDT
Ohio Republican J.D.
A Thiel spokesperson did not respond to a request for comment.
Thiel is Vance's biggest patron.
J.D.
